projects.graph

Interface Graph

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AdjacencyListGraph, AdjacencyMatrixGraph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

    public interface Graph

    Graph is an abstraction over directed and weighted graphs. It supports insertion of nodes, insertion and removal of edges, queries of connectedness, simple accessors, as well as shortest path computation using Dijkstra's algorithm.

    Nodes in Graph are simplistic in that they are characterized just by an increasing index. So, the first node inserted would be considered node 0 (zero), the second one node 1 and so on and so forth. For this reason, removal of nodes from a Graph instance is not supported, otherwise inconsistencies with the internal representation of the instance could occur. For example, if we have 8 nodes and we remove the first one inserted, should we consider a new node to have index 9 or 8? It's unclear, so we just let go of the requirement.

    Author:
    Jason Filippou
    See Also:
    AdjacencyMatrixGraph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph, AdjacencyListGraph

    • Method Detail

      • addNode

        void addNode()

        Add a new node to the graph. The node will be characterized by its index of insertion, such that the first time this method is called, a node with index ' 0 ' is stored in the graph, the second one we will store a node with index 1, etc, etc.

      • addEdge

        void addEdge(int source,
             int target,
             int weight)

        Adds an edge from node source to node target in the graph, attaching to it weight weight. In this implementation, we allow weights to be negative; the utility of a negative weight edge would depend on the application. If the edge already exists, ts weight should be updated to the parameter value.

        If either source or target don't exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined. This means that you can do whatever you want, as long as you don't store extra edges or nodes in the graph. You can throw a RuntimeException, return null, print a message, anything. We do not test for this case.

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The "sink" node of the edge.
        weight - The weight of the edge.

      • deleteEdge

        void deleteEdge(int source,
                int target)

        Delete the edge from source to target. If the edge does not exist, or if either node does not exist in the graph, you should perform no action. That is to say, in contrast with addEdge(int, int, int), where you were free to take any action, in this case you should take no action (or, at least, no action that would cause subsequent public method calls to leave your graph in an inconsistent state.

        We would like to particularly stress that removing an edge does not in any way imply removing its constituent nodes, even if the nodes end up being singleton disconnected components!

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The "sink" node of the edge.

      • isConnected

        boolean isConnected(int source,
                    int target)

        Queries the graph about the existence of an edge from source to target. If either source or target are not contained by the graph, then the edge itself cannot possibly exist.

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, source, target and the edge source->target all exist in the graph, false otherwise.

      • getEdgeWeight

        int getEdgeWeight(int source,
                  int target)
        Returns the weight of the edge source->target
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The " sink " of the edge.
